content: Japan's financial crisis in the late 1980s began with stock market and real estate bubbles fueled by excess liquidity. Investors and speculators were drawn to the rapidly rising market values, leading to risky investments. Banks considered loans with real estate collateral as secure, but when the bubbles burst, the Nikkei stock market average peaked. The bursting of Japan's financial bubble in the late 1980s led to a significant decline in the Nikkei stock market average and real estate values. Banks suffered as the value of their stock holdings and capital reserves plummeted, causing collateral underlying many bank loans to drop below their value. Commercial land values in major metropolitan areas fell by 80% and residential/industrial land values by nearly 20%. The bursting of Japan's financial bubble in the late 1980s led to a significant decline in land values in major metropolitan areas. Residential and industrial land values fell by nearly 20%, causing collateral underlying bank loans to drop below their value. This economic crisis also impacted commercial real estate ventures, leading to unprofitable office buildings and a slowdown in the overall Japanese economy. The selling bank would extend credit to the CCPC for the purchase cost of the non-performing loan, allowing the bank to count the gap between the loan principal and selling price as a capital loss for tax purposes. However, this fiscal tightening led to a prolonged recession as the government overestimated economic recovery. By 2003, debt-to-GDP ratio was 141% and deficit to GDP ratio was 5.4%. The bursting of the real estate bubble in Japan caused more difficulty for banks than the stock market bubble. The bursting of the real estate bubble in Japan caused more difficulty for banks than the stock market bubble due to the decline in real estate values affecting collateral on bank lending. Japan's slow response to monetary and fiscal policies, as well as banking sector issues, worsened the situation. Tightening fiscal policy too soon after the economy began to recover was also seen as a mistake.
